p: The inhibition activities of α-glucosidase and α-amylase using natural PSEs [ 26] and FSEs synthesized in our laboratory [ 26, 27] depended on the structural features of these compounds. Therefore, CSEs 2– 9 were specifically designed to differ in: (i) the number of cinnamoyl moieties, (ii) the degree of acetylation of the sucrose core, and (iii) the presence or absence of the diisopropylidene bridges on sucrose core ( Figure 2). These bridges control the degree of flexibility between the glucose and fructose moieties of the sucrose core. CSEs 2– 9 were also designed to complement and compare with our inhibition studies using a small library of FSEs such as 1 ( Figure 2). CSEs 2– 9 were synthesized by cinnamoylation of 2,1′:4,6-di- O-isopropylidene sucrose with cinnamoyl chlorides in dry pyridine according to our previous work ( Scheme 1) [ 19]. Acetylation of the cinnamoylated compounds was then achieved using acetic anhydride to give the acetylated CSEs [ 19].
